repnme.cdata!:
Bahamas - New Providence Island Water
            Supply and Sewerage Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the New Providence Island
            Water Supply and Sewerage Rehabilitation Project for Bahamas
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project
            sustainability was likely, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: except for
            improvements in the financial position of Water and Sewerage
            Corporation (WSC) the project objectives have for the most
            part been met. Improvements in management and operations
            have been realized, there have been improvements in water
            quality and reliability, leak detection and control program
            is being systematically installed with meter replacement
            underway, and improvements in the transport of water have
            been successful. Nonetheless there have been some important
            shortcomings in the project, which are reflected in the
            following findings and lessons learned. Most of them focus
            on financial issues facing WSC. One of the major findings
            concerns the recent technological developments which have
            been achieved in producing potable water from seawater by
            Reverse Osmosis (RO). Many of the principal hotels, which
            are large water consumers, have begun to explore alternative
            water supply sources to ensure that their water supply needs
            are met at a reasonable cost. With the growing viability of
            the reverse-osmosis (RO) alternative, independent water
            production has become competitive with existing services.
            WSC's past inability to provide consistent, high
            quality water at a reasonable price has resulted in a loss
            of clients. To avoid further erosion of the hotel customer
            base, WSC service to the remaining hotels will need to match
            client expectations in terms of cost and service
            reliability. More aggressive efforts to improve operational
            efficiency by reducing continued high levels of Unaccounted
            for Water (UFW) should, in turn, ensure a more consistent,
            reliable and cost-effective supply of water.

repnme.cdata!:
Bahamas - New Providence Island Water
            Supply and Sewerage Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Through the New Providence Island Water
            Supply and Sewerage Rehabilitation Project, the country
            hopes to improve the Water and Sewerage Corporation (WSC) in
            the key areas of management and finance.  It also seeks to
            promote system reliability and performance through the
            rehabilitation of deteriorating facilities and by
            improvements in their operation and maintenance.  To this
            end, the project, to be carried out over eight years
            supports several components.  They include water supply
            rehabilitation, water importation improvements, sewerage
            rehabilitation, acquisition of various equipment and a
            comprehensive program of technical assistance and training.
            Under the proposed project, increasing efficiency and cost
            savings will accrue along with improved water quality, as
            well as better water supply and sewerage service.  A
            well-functioning water supply and sewerage system is vital
            to the health of the population and of the tourism industry,
            on which the economy of the Bahamas is critically dependent.
